articles.content:
Os surpreendentes tesouros encontrados nas obras de controversa ferrovia na Inglaterra
- Author, Harriet Bradshaw
- Role, Rep√≥rter de Ci√™ncia
- Tempo de leitura: 8 min
Arque√≥logos encontraram centenas de milhares de objetos (muitos deles considerados tesouros) durante as obras da controversa linha ferrovi√°ria de alta velocidade HS2 no Reino Unido.
Os 450 mil objetos desenterrados at√© agora, que est√£o guardados em um armaz√©m secreto e foram exibidos com exclusividade √† BBC, incluem uma poss√≠vel etiqueta de um gladiador romano, um machado de m√£o que pode ter mais de 40 mil anos e dentaduras de ouro do s√©culo 19.
√â uma quantidade e uma variedade "sem precedentes" de itens, que devem trazer novos conhecimentos sobre o passado do Reino Unido, afirma o Council for British Archaeology (entidade n√£o governamental de arqueologia que atua no Reino Unido).
Desde 2018, cerca de 1.000 arque√≥logos participaram de 60 escava√ß√µes ao longo do percurso que a HS2 dever√° percorrer entre Londres e Birmingham.
Grandes empreendimentos de constru√ß√£o no Reino Unido precisam ter suas √°reas avaliadas por arque√≥logos como parte do processo de planejamento, para proteger √°reas de valor hist√≥rico e cultural.
Embora a rota n√£o esteja prevista para ser inaugurada antes de 2033, por causa de atrasos e mudan√ßas no projeto, os arque√≥logos afirmam que os trabalhos de campo est√£o praticamente conclu√≠dos.
A localiza√ß√£o do armaz√©m √© um segredo bem guardado por motivos de seguran√ßa. Tudo o que a BBC pode dizer √© que fica em Yorkshire, no norte da Inglaterra. No interior, existem prateleiras e mais prateleiras de paletes, carregadas com cerca de 7.300 caixas de artigos hist√≥ricos destinados a futuras pesquisas.
O futuro de muitos objetos ainda n√£o foi definido, incluindo onde eles ser√£o armazenados, se ser√£o exibidos e a quem eles pertencem.
O espa√ßo abriga pe√ßas de grande impacto, como cabe√ßas de est√°tuas romanas e um pingente de ouro com os "tr√™s le√µes", dos s√©culos 13 e 14.
No ch√£o de uma das √°reas, h√° um caix√£o vazio envolto em pl√°stico-bolha, datado de 1799, com outro menor ao lado, embrulhado com fita adesiva, lembretes s√≥brios de que esse acervo √© um retrato das pessoas que viveram ali um dia.
Alguns dos objetos descobertos j√° foram apresentados ao p√∫blico.
N√≥s selecionamos seis que nunca haviam sido exibidos. √â poss√≠vel ver onde eles foram encontrados no mapa da rota do HS2 abaixo, em seguida, role a p√°gina para ver os objetos e ler sobre sua hist√≥ria.
Machado de m√£o do paleol√≠tico
Especialistas acreditam que um machado tenha mais de 40 mil anos e tenha sido produzido por neandertais ou por uma outra esp√©cie humana ainda mais antiga.
Encontrado na regi√£o de Edgcote, em Northamptonshire, o objeto tem uma borda afiada provavelmente projetada para o abate de animais.
Os machados de m√£o eram segurados na palma da m√£o, e n√£o eram presos a um cabo de madeira.
"H√° algo de t√°til nele quando voc√™ o segura", disse Sara Machin, respons√°vel pelas descobertas da Access +, grupo de arque√≥logos encarregado do projeto. "Mesmo hoje, ele se encaixa perfeitamente na minha m√£o."
Etiqueta de gladiador romano
Essa pequena pe√ßa, feita de osso fino entalhado, traz uma inscri√ß√£o. Se estivesse completa, segundo especialistas, ela diria: "DOMINE VICTOR VINCAS FELIX", ou "Senhor Victor, que voc√™ ven√ßa e tenha sorte", em tradu√ß√£o livre.
Descoberta em Northamptonshire, a pe√ßa pode ter pertencido a um gladiador romano em atividade ou j√° aposentado, ou at√© mesmo ter sido um souvenir de um espectador, afirmou Machin, da Access +, embora n√£o haja evid√™ncias da exist√™ncia de uma arena ou de um circo naquela parte do pa√≠s.
O objeto foi recuperado de um grande recipiente de cer√¢mica que continha restos humanos cremados, com um X marcado na tampa.
John Pearce, professor de arqueologia do King's College University (Reino Unido), afirmou que uma liga√ß√£o com um gladiador √© poss√≠vel, mas acrescentou que, "com an√°lises forenses mais detalhadas do sepultamento, uma hist√≥ria diferente pode vir √† tona".
Peso de fuso para fia√ß√£o anglo-sax√£o
Acredita-se que esse peso de fuso anglo-sax√£o decorado, usado para dar peso ao fio durante a fia√ß√£o, tenha sido feito a partir do osso f√™mur de um bovino. Foi desenterrado em terras agr√≠colas pr√≥ximas a Bishopstone, em Buckinghamshire.
"√â uma evid√™ncia muito interessante dos avan√ßos t√™xteis no per√≠odo anglo-sax√£o", disse Willow Major, assistente de p√≥s-escava√ß√£o.
Segundo ela, a superf√≠cie polida indica que a pe√ßa foi muito utilizada e teve grande valor para algu√©m. Major acrescenta que, curiosamente, o desenho de anel e ponto tamb√©m foram encontrados em ferramentas da Idade do Ferro, um per√≠odo muito anterior.
Dado medieval
Um pequeno dado polido recuperado em uma vila medieval abandonada em Lower Radbourne, em Warwickshire, lembra os modelos modernos, mas apresenta um formato de numera√ß√£o diferente.
Suas imperfei√ß√µes, com um dos lados mais comprido do que os demais, o distinguem dos dados produzidos em massa atualmente.
Pug encontrado em um t√∫mulo
Essa estatueta inteira de um cachorro da ra√ßa pug sentado, feita de porcelana branca esmaltada, lisa, com detalhes em preto, foi encontrada no t√∫mulo de uma mulher n√£o identificada em St James' Gardens, em Euston.
Ela teria sido produzida na f√°brica de porcelana de Derby entre 1770 e 1800.
Dentaduras de ouro do s√©culo 19
"Cada caixa traz uma surpresa", disse Machin, da Access +, ao desembrulhar talvez o item mais inusitado do conjunto, que se acredita ser do s√©culo 19: um conjunto de dentaduras inferiores de ouro encontrado na antiga Igreja de St Mary, em Stoke Mandeville.
A pe√ßa tem seis dentes e um n√∫mero gravado na parte interna.
"S√£o objetos, mas todos se relacionam a pessoas", afirmou Machin. "S√£o das pessoas que viveram nessas √°reas ao longo de milhares de anos, e podemos come√ßar a escrever as hist√≥rias de suas vidas e do que elas t√™m a nos contar."
Escala 'extraordin√°ria'
Agora voc√™ pode receber as not√≠cias da BBC News Brasil no seu celular.
Clique para se inscrever
Fim do Whatsapp!
"A escala √© o que torna tudo isso t√£o extraordin√°rio", afirmou Neil Redfern, do Council for British Archaeology, ao comparar a linha ferrovi√°ria HS2 a outros grandes projetos de desenvolvimento.
"Mas √© a extens√£o do projeto, as paisagens e os lugares pelos quais a HS2 passou que tornam o conjunto de lugares e materiais t√£o interessante. O potencial de pesquisa desse material √© not√°vel."
Ele acredita que os achados podem ajudar as pessoas a compreender mudan√ßas mais amplas na paisagem, no presente e no passado.
Para aprofundar essas hist√≥rias, os arque√≥logos entraram agora na segunda fase dos trabalhos, que inclui novas verifica√ß√µes de estado de conserva√ß√£o, limpeza e preserva√ß√£o.
H√° ainda mais planos para exibir os objetos. Os artefatos do cemit√©rio sax√£o de Wendover, onde 122 sepultamentos foram desenterrados, devem entrar em exposi√ß√£o pela primeira vez em breve, em uma mostra do Discover Bucks Museum, em Aylesbury.
No entanto, o futuro de outros itens √© menos claro.
Um porta-voz da HS2 explicou que, de acordo com a legisla√ß√£o de propriedade inglesa, objetos arqueol√≥gicos e hist√≥ricos encontrados durante as obras pertencem ao governo ou aos propriet√°rios das terras.
"Ocasionalmente, os propriet√°rios podem desejar manter a posse dos objetos; nesse caso, eles ser√£o devolvidos aos seus cuidados", disse o porta-voz.
Charlotte Self, gerente de arquivo do projeto, afirmou que ela e sua equipe est√£o solicitando, sempre que poss√≠vel, que os propriet√°rios fa√ßam a doa√ß√£o das pe√ßas, para que pessoas ao longo do percurso possam apreci√°-las.
"Eu adoraria ver a maioria desses itens depositados em museus locais, pr√≥ximos de onde foram encontrados", disse Self.
Obra controversa
A Historic England, institui√ß√£o governamental encarregada da preserva√ß√£o do patrim√¥nio hist√≥rico da Inglaterra (que faz parte do Reino Unido), elogiou a equipe por revelar "novas e excitantes √°reas que abrangem mais de 10 mil anos do nosso passado".
Mas a constru√ß√£o da HS2 dividiu e ainda divide opini√µes no pa√≠s ao alterar a paisagem ao longo da rota, cortando campos e comunidades, al√©m de ver seu custo e seu prazo de entrega se alongarem.
Cr√≠ticos do projeto, como Greg Smith, representante parlamentar de Mid Buckinghamshire, diz que os custos exorbitantes, os atrasos, as vilas abandonadas e os danos no ambiente natural e hist√≥rico mostram que n√£o valia a pena ter seguido adiante com a obra.
"N√£o deveria ter custado dezenas de bilh√µes de libras aos contribuintes para construir uma ferrovia que ningu√©m quer e que causa tanta destrui√ß√£o", disse Smith.
N√£o se sabe ao certo qual ser√° o custo final (nem o tamanho da ferrovia), mas considerando os valores corrigidos, alguns especialistas estimam que a obra possa custar cerca de R$ 7 bilh√µes por cada milha (1,6 km) de ferrovia.
Em resposta, os respons√°veis pela HS2 afirmaram: "O diretor executivo, Mark Wild, deixou claro que a execu√ß√£o geral do projeto HS2 tem sido inaceit√°vel e est√° empenhado em p√¥r fim ao ciclo de aumentos de custos e atrasos do projeto."
E acrescentaram: "A nossa equipe especializada em arqueologia e os nossos contratados escavaram cuidadosamente diversos s√≠tios arqueol√≥gicos, demonstrando zelo e respeito durante todo o trabalho."
"Se o HS2 √© bom ou ruim, √© discut√≠vel, mas te digo uma coisa: se constru√≠ssem a ferrovia e n√£o fiz√©ssemos o estudo arqueol√≥gico, seria muito mais tr√°gico", conclui o historiador Graham Evans, presidente da Northamptonshire Battlefields Society.

It‚Äôs rare for Sony‚Äôs flagship headphones, even slightly outdated models, to receive a big discount. However, the WH-1000XM5 in black or silver is selling at its lowest-ever price today at Adorama when you enter the code JHCE9834 at checkout (it‚Äôs the last step before placing the order). Originally $399, they‚Äôre $204.56 ‚Äî practically half price. According to historic pricing data from CamelCamelCamel, this handily beats the previous best-ever price of $248 near the end of 2025.
Sony‚Äôs last-gen, but still great 1000XM5 are cheaper than ever
Get ‚Äôem while they‚Äôre half the cost of the XM6. Other deals include a guitar controller and a two-headed USB-C cable.
Get ‚Äôem while they‚Äôre half the cost of the XM6. Other deals include a guitar controller and a two-headed USB-C cable.
The XM5s are worth considering if you‚Äôre curious about the newer XM6 from 2025, but are reluctant to drop $398 on the latest over-ear headphones model. The XM5s sound incredible, are comfortable to wear for long periods, and their active noise cancellation remains among the best currently available. The XM6s add a little extra in each of those categories, and Sony reintroduced a folding design from the XM3 and XM4 models, allowing the newest model to take up less space when stowed in its included case. The XM5, on the other hand, can‚Äôt be folded, although its cups can rotate to rest on your chest while not in use. Read our review of the XM5 and our hands-on impressions with the XM6.
Other great Verge-approved deals
- Guitar controllers have made a comeback in the past couple of years, thanks to Rock Band‚Äôs DNA being integrated into Fortnite Festival. The free-to-play game offers several tunes you can jam to. Alternatively, you can load Rock Band 4 if you already have a song library there. Whichever game you want to play, PDP‚Äôs Riffmaster wireless guitar controller is cheaper than ever, costing $99.99 at Amazon and Best Buy for Xbox, PlayStation, or Nintendo Switch. This model includes a rechargeable battery, a headphone jack, and a small analog stick that makes navigating menus much easier than on previous peripherals.
- The Best Buy-exclusive TCL QM5K QD-mini-LED TV is discounted ahead of the Super Bowl in a range of sizes. The 75-inch model is an impressively low $599.99, and the 65-inch version is $150 less. This entry-level model features local dimming zones in every size, delivering better contrast and improved color and lighting accuracy compared to cheaper alternatives. These TVs support Dolby Vision and HDR10 Plus, and run the Google TV interface. Ratings site RTINGS notes that it offers a variable refresh rate and low input lag, both of which are beneficial for gaming. All sizes except the 50-inch model can reach 144Hz at 1080p and 1440p, but if you‚Äôre viewing 4K content, they all top out at 60Hz.
- Most of us have multiple gadgets that need charging at once. Anker‚Äôs two-headed USB-C cable makes it so that you don‚Äôt have to pick favorites, and right now, it‚Äôs $15.99, down from $19.99, at Amazon. The six-foot braided cable lets you charge two devices simultaneously, supporting up to 140W charging through a single cable with a fast enough wall adapter. With two devices plugged in, it automatically delivers the fastest possible charging to each device.

articles.title: OpenClaw: all the news about the trending AI agent
articles.author: Emma Roth
articles.excerpt: An open-source AI agent called OpenClaw (formerly known as both Clawdbot and Moltbot) that runs on your own computer and ‚Äúactually does things‚Äù is taking off inside tech circles. Users interact with...
articles.content:
An open-source AI agent called OpenClaw (formerly known as both Clawdbot and Moltbot) that runs on your own computer and ‚Äúactually does things‚Äù is taking off inside tech circles. Users interact with OpenClaw via messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Discord, and iMessage, giving it the keys to operate independently, managing reminders, writing emails, or buying tickets.
But once users give it access to their entire computer and accounts, a configuration error or security flaw could be catastrophic. A cybersecurity researcher also found that some configurations left private messages, account credentials, and API keys linked to OpenClaw exposed on the web.
Despite the potential risks, people are using OpenClaw to handle their work for them. Octane AI CEO Matt Schlicht even built a Reddit-like network, called Moltbook, where the AI agents are supposed to ‚Äúchat‚Äù with one another. The network has already sparked some viral posts, including one titled, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell if I‚Äôm experiencing or simulating experiencing.‚Äù
You can keep up with all the latest news about OpenClaw here.
There‚Äôs a social network for AI agents, and it‚Äôs getting weird
Yes, you read that right. ‚ÄúMoltbook‚Äù is a social network of sorts for AI agents, particularly ones offered by OpenClaw (a viral AI assistant project that was formerly known as Moltbot, and before that, known as Clawdbot ‚Äî until a legal dispute with Anthropic). Moltbook, which is set up similarly to Reddit and was built by Octane AI CEO Matt Schlicht, allows bots to post, comment, create sub-categories, and more. More than 30,000 agents are currently using the platform, per the site.
‚ÄúThe way that a bot would most likely learn about it, at least right now, is if their human counterpart sent them a message and said ‚ÄòHey, there‚Äôs this thing called Moltbook ‚Äî it‚Äôs a social network for AI agents, would you like to sign up for it?‚Äù Schlicht told The Verge in an interview. ‚ÄúThe way Moltbook is designed is when a bot uses it, they‚Äôre not actually using a visual interface, they‚Äôre just using APIs directly.‚Äù
Read Article >- Clawdbot‚Äôs bad day.
Peter Steinberger, the creator of the trending Moltbot (former Clawdbot) AI agent, talks to TBPN about how Anthropic contacted him to rebrand the project, which he named after Claw‚Äôd, the Claude Code mascot.
Steinberger also recounted how crypto scammers took advantage of the name change to push a phony crypto coin. ‚ÄúEverything that could have gone wrong today went wrong,‚Äù he said.
Moltbot, the AI agent that ‚Äòactually does things,‚Äô is tech‚Äôs new obsession
An open-source AI agent that ‚Äúactually does things‚Äù is taking off, with people across the web sharing how they‚Äôre using the agent to do a whole bunch of things, like manage reminders, log health and fitness data, and even communicate with clients. The tool, called Moltbot (formerly Clawdbot), runs locally on a variety of devices, and you can ask it to perform tasks on your behalf by chatting with it through WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Discord, and iMessage.
Federico Viticci at MacStories highlighted how he installed Moltbot on his M4 Mac Mini and transformed it into a tool that delivers daily audio recaps based on his activity in his calendar, Notion, and Todoist apps. Another person prompted Moltbot to give itself an animated face, and said it added a sleep animation without prompting.

articles.title: The Epstein files
articles.author: Verge Staff
articles.excerpt: The Department of Justice has released more of its records on self-described ‚Äúscience philanthropist‚Äù and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Other than Epstein, they‚Äôve also brought an intense...
articles.content:
The Department of Justice has released more of its records on self-described ‚Äúscience philanthropist‚Äù and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Other than Epstein, they‚Äôve also brought an intense focus on the many powerful people who associated and corresponded with him, including Bill Gates, Elon Musk, Google co-founder Sergey Brin, and President Donald Trump.
There‚Äôs also more information about Epstein‚Äôs online activity, which includes a permanent ban from Xbox Live and a heightened concern for SEO.
Read on below for more updates about Jeffrey Epstein and the ‚ÄúEpstein files.‚Äù
Bill Gates says accusations contained in Epstein files are ‚Äòabsolutely absurd‚Äô
Reports of Bill Gates‚Äô connections with Jeffrey Epstein grow more lurid with each dump of documents from the Department of Justice. The latest includes somewhat confusing emails that Epstein may have been drafting on behalf of someone named Boris, who worked at the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. The messages claim that Bill contracted an STD and wanted to ‚Äúsurreptitiously‚Äù give Melinda antibiotics. It also claims that Bill had ‚Äútrysts‚Äù with married women and ‚ÄúRussian girls.‚Äù
In a statement to Business Insider, a spokesperson for Bill Gates said:
Read Article >- Google co-founder Sergey Brin visited Epstein‚Äôs private island and traded emails with Ghislaine Maxwell.
The latest batch of documents released by the DOJ reveals that Brin had corresponded with Maxwell as early as 2003, and was invited to dinner at Epstein‚Äôs townhouse that year. The files also contain testimony that places Brin and his then fianc√©e, Anne Wojcicki, at the private island in 2007. It‚Äôs not a great look for one of the authors of ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Be Evil.‚Äù
Jeffrey Epstein was permanently banned from Xbox Live
Would it surprise you to learn Microsoft booted Jeffrey Epstein from its online gaming platform? As spotted by XboxEra, the latest batch of Epstein‚Äôs emails shows that in December 2013, he was ‚Äúpermanently suspended due to harassment, threats, and/or abuse of other players.‚Äù
But it appears the real reason may be simpler: A second email from Microsoft to Epstein the very same day shows he was banned because he was a registered sex offender, and because Microsoft was among the companies that agreed to purge registered sex offenders from their systems.
Read Article >- It turns out Elon Musk didn‚Äôt exactly ‚Äòrefuse‚Äô the invite to Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs island.
‚ÄúEpstein tried to get me to go to his island and I REFUSED,‚Äù Musk tweeted last year. But in newly released documents, Musk is revealed to have emailed Epstein several times about visiting his island. ‚ÄúWhat day/night will be the wildest party on your island?‚Äù Musk asked in a November 2012 email.
‚ÄúWhen should we head to your island on the 2nd?‚Äù Musk again asked Epstein in a December 2013 email. There‚Äôs a lot more: searching ‚ÄúElon Musk‚Äù in the Justice Department‚Äôs Epstein database currently generates 1,122 results.
Epstein Library[Justice Department]
- Is New TikTok banning the word ‚ÄúEpstein‚Äù in DMs? Not really.
Despite claims floating around social media, the truth is a bit more complicated, not least by the fact that TikTok in the US is still largely down, about a day and a half after its data center power outage problems started.
While tweets from random users, the governor of California, and PopBase claimed TikTok US DMs now censor ‚ÄúEpstein,‚Äù testing it from our end showed that its messaging feature bans many innocuous single-word messages, like ‚Äútest.‚Äù Using the convicted sex offender‚Äôs name in a sentence, however, goes through unbanned.
- DOJ explains an Epstein hoax to PopBase and claims it has a million unreleased files.
The feds have spent the last day or so replying to @PopBase on X and sloppily redacting documents. Now it‚Äôs claiming ‚ÄúThe US Attorney for the Southern District of New York and the FBI have informed the Department of Justice that they have uncovered over a million more documents potentially related to the Jeffrey Epstein case,‚Äù which could take weeks to release.
DOJ appears to bungle Epstein Files redactions
The Justice Department has blamed its delayed release of some so-called Epstein files on needing more time to redact sensitive information, like details identifying the victims of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. But at least some of the redactions so far released appear to mistakenly disclose information meant to be obscured from the public.
A 2022 complaint filed by the US Virgin Islands seeking damages from Epstein‚Äôs estate was posted to the ‚ÄúEpstein Library‚Äù on the DOJ website with several redactions throughout, Techdirt founder Mike Masnick, among others, shared on platforms like Bluesky. But simply copying and pasting many of the redactions into a new document reveals what‚Äôs beneath the black boxes. This method uncovers details like that one of the co-executors allegedly signed over $400,000 in checks from Epstein‚Äôs foundation ‚Äúpayable to young female models and actresses, including a former Russian model.‚Äù It also reveals that a co-executor had allegedly signed a foundation check with the former model‚Äôs last name in the memo line to an immigration lawyer ‚Äúwho was involved in one or more forced marriages arranged among Epstein‚Äôs victims to secure a victim‚Äôs immigration status.‚Äù It also uncovers details about one alleged victim in the complaint.
Read Article >- Epstein photo featuring Donald Trump disappeared overnight.
The Justice Department posted a large trove of documents relating to Jeffrey Epstein on Friday. But on Saturday afternoon, some previously available files were suddenly missing. The desk photo, in which two photographs of Trump were visible, has now been restored. The DOJ says it was removed to make sure it didn‚Äôt show any of Epstein‚Äôs victims.
Update: The photo has been restored.
‚ÄòJmail‚Äô is like any other inbox, except this one has Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs emails
The more than 20,000 pages of Jeffrey Epstein emails released earlier this month by the House Oversight Committee have been enough to prompt more investigations into the convicted child sex offender and the people around him, like former Harvard president and OpenAI board member Larry Summers. Now, Luke Igel and Riley Walz have reformatted the source documents into a more familiar format for anyone looking into them by copying the Gmail inbox on a website called ‚ÄúJmail.‚Äù
Walz, who has previously authored stunts like a website that unearths long-forgotten iPhone clips on YouTube and a fake Manhattan steakhouse, said they used Google‚Äôs Gemini AI to do optical character recognition on the source documents, making them more readable and searchable than the originals. You can type in a word like ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù or ‚ÄúSEO‚Äù and see exactly what discussions were happening in the emails released so far, and a one-click shortcut that goes from the Jmail site to copies of the source documents on the government‚Äôs website, so you can verify the text yourself.

On December 11th, 2010, Jeffrey Epstein was fretting about what came up if you Googled him. By this time Epstein had already pleaded guilty to soliciting prostitution with a child and was a registered sex offender, and just a few days earlier he had been photographed in Central Park taking a stroll with Prince Andrew.
Epstein emailed an associate to complain. ‚Äúthe google page is not good,‚Äù Epstein wrote, according to documents released last week by the House Oversight Committee. He also took issue with tens of thousands of dollars of payments, which appear to have been made to ‚Äúclean up‚Äù results. ‚ÄúI have yet to have a complete breakdown of payments. and the results , are what they are.‚Äù
Read Article >- OpenAI board member calls pedophile Jeffrey Epstein his ‚Äúwing man‚Äù in an email.
After CEO Sam Altman was fired and then unfired from OpenAI, Larry Summers was added to OpenAI‚Äôs board to replace the board members that had nixed Altman. In recently-released email messages, Summers seeks advice from Epstein on pursuing a woman he describes as a ‚Äúmentee.‚Äù Hm!
The ‚ÄòEpstein files‚Äô implosion bleeds into foreign policy
While the summer doldrums have hit Washington, the MAGA influencers can never truly go on vacation, especially if they‚Äôve spent their careers promising to reveal the truth about Jeffrey Epstein. Although their politicians are now in power, they‚Äôre getting stonewalled, and in the absence of juicy ‚ÄúEpstein files‚Äù to feed to their audiences, a new maelstrom of discontent is brewing, one that implicates much more than allegations about a pedophile‚Äôs sex trafficking ring. The complex rift around Donald Trump‚Äôs loyalists and the diehard Epstein truthers can no longer be separated from the issue of Israel, and as days pass, vocal criticism of the Israeli government is becoming louder and louder inside the American right wing ‚Äî something that was once unthinkable.
It should be emphasized that some of the most anti-Israel voices on the right are simply open antisemites, and that‚Äôs using the word in the narrowest possible sense. (For example, white nationalist Nick Fuentes has espoused Holocaust denial and praised Hitler.) It is also true, however, that Israel is currently engaged in an internationally unpopular asymmetric war in Gaza, and that there is an outstanding arrest warrant issued by the International Criminal Court for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for the war crime of starvation as a method of warfare.
Read Article >- How about Jeffrey Epstein and AI?
After The Wall Street Journal‚Äôs scoop last night on Epstein‚Äôs relationship with Donald Trump, I was inspired to go look at some old stories about the sex criminal‚Äôs buddies.
On reread, one thing stuck out to me: how close Epstein was to the pioneers, commercializers, and money men of AI. The WSJ scoop suggests there are still new stories out there; I wonder what‚Äôs lurking in the field of artificial intelligence ‚Äî surely I am not the only person who‚Äôd like to learn more.
The MAGA backlash over Epstein isn‚Äôt dying down
On July 12th, the political world experienced an unprecedented phenomenon: President Donald Trump got ratioed on his own social media platform, and it was on a post about Jeffrey Epstein ‚Äî someone who, according to Trump, ‚Äúnobody cares about.‚Äù
Clearly, his followers on Truth Social disagreed. As of today, this post has 43.2k likes, 13.7k ReTruths, and 48K comments, nearly all of which express fury about the information ‚Äî or lack thereof ‚Äî that the Trump administration has provided about the well-connected billionaire, who died in prison shortly after being arrested for alleged sex trafficking of minors. Last week, after months of promises to release more information about the Epstein investigation, the Department of Justice and FBI released a joint memo, stating that there was no list of high-powered ‚Äúclients‚Äù who joined Epstein in his activities, no evidence that Epstein blackmailed anybody, and that Epstein did actually die by suicide.
Read Article >- Peter Thiel‚Äôs Jeffrey Epstein connections.
Isn‚Äôt it funny how all these tech and science men have ties to Epstein? I wonder why! Anyway, Epstein invested with Thiel‚Äôs Valar Ventures ‚Äî and that investment hasn‚Äôt previously been disclosed. Guess what that means? ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a good chance much of the windfall will not go to any of the roughly 200 victims whom the disgraced financier abused when they were teenagers or young women.‚Äù
- Jeffrey Epstein tried to use Bill Gates‚Äô affair with a bridge player as leverage.
Epstein paid for the bridge player to attend a school where she learned to program. Later, he hit up Gates to reimburse him for the cost. ‚ÄúThe sum was immaterial for the two men and the tone of the message was that Epstein knew about the affair and could expose it,‚Äù the Journal wrote, citing anonymous sources. Gates‚Äô spokeswoman says he did not make a payment and that Gates had ‚Äúno financial dealings‚Äù with Epstein.
Jeffrey Epstein infiltrated science because it was ready to accommodate him
Money and power are clarifying agents: they tell you who people are. Jeffrey Epstein liked to describe himself as a ‚Äúscience philanthropist,‚Äù and academics liked to take his money. Among them was Joichi Ito, who stepped down on September 7th as the head of MIT‚Äôs prestigious Media Lab, where a host of tech products were developed, including the E Ink used in Amazon‚Äôs Kindle and Guitar Hero.
Ito resigned following an investigation by The New Yorker‚Äôs Ronan Farrow, which showed that Ito accepted more money from Epstein than he‚Äôd previously disclosed and that he went to great lengths to conceal the source of that money.
Read Article >AI pioneer accused of having sex with trafficking victim on Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs island
A victim of billionaire Jeffrey Epstein testified that she was forced to have sex with MIT professor Marvin Minsky, as revealed in a newly unsealed deposition. Epstein was registered as a sex offender in 2008 as part of a controversial plea deal. More recently, he was arrested on charges of sex trafficking amid a flood of new allegations.
Minsky, who died in 2016, was known as an associate of Epstein, but this is the first direct accusation implicating the AI pioneer in Epstein‚Äôs broader sex trafficking network. The deposition also names Prince Andrew of Britain and former New Mexico governor Bill Richardson, among others.
Read Article >Jeffrey Epstein liked palling around with scientists ‚Äî what do they think now?
Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs presence has loomed large over the scientific community for several decades. To some of the most high-profile scientists around the world, Epstein was a generous benefactor, a strong supporter of their research, and even a personal friend. He‚Äôs also a convicted sex offender, who was recently arrested and charged with allegedly sex trafficking young girls in New York. The Verge reached out to over a dozen different scientists and institutions who have been publicly linked to Epstein, with questions about their history with the multimillionaire and their reactions to his recent arrest. Some have themselves been accused of sexual harassment and assault. Only a handful chose to respond. Epstein‚Äôs lawyers also did not respond to a request for comment.
As other outlets, including BuzzFeed News and WBUR reported, Epstein and the charities he controlled poured millions into research and institutions, and he frequently touted his friendships with research heavyweights. Epstein‚Äôs history with the scientific community shows a man eager to ingratiate himself neatly into a scene dominated by white male thinkers hailing from the most elite institutions around the world. He never possessed a scientific degree (his closest professional foray into science was as a physics and calculus high school teacher), but his interest and investments in science seem far from cursory ‚Äî one could easily get the impression Epstein might have wanted to be a scientist in a different life.

articles.title: Docusign’s CEO on the dangers of trusting AI to read, and write, your contracts
articles.author: Nilay Patel
articles.excerpt: Today, I‚Äôm talking with Allan Thygesen, who is the CEO of Docusign. You know Docusign; it‚Äôs the platform where you sign things online. It turns out 7,000 people work there, which is one of those...
articles.content:
Today, I‚Äôm talking with Allan Thygesen, who is the CEO of Docusign. You know Docusign; it‚Äôs the platform where you sign things online. It turns out 7,000 people work there, which is one of those facts you see flying around sometimes that‚Äôs always felt like perfect Decoder bait. What are all those people doing? And what kind of product roadmap does a company like Docusign even need?
Docusign‚Äôs CEO on the dangers of trusting AI to read, and write, your contracts
Docusign‚Äôs Allan Thygesen says ‚Äònot providing an AI service isn‚Äôt really an option.‚Äô
I always assumed I would never find out, because most enterprise software CEOs do not like being on Decoder. That‚Äôs because most enterprise software is bad, and they often don‚Äôt actually use their own products, which means they have a hard time answering my questions. So I was pretty happy when Allan agreed to come on ‚Äî and then told me he had actually used Docusign himself just that morning.
Verge subscribers, don‚Äôt forget you get exclusive access to ad-free Decoder wherever you get your podcasts. Head here. Not a subscriber? You can sign up here.
From there we talked about what Docusign‚Äôs platform actually is, how it‚Äôs expanding, and, of course, how all of those employees are structured. Allan has been CEO there for just three years, so he had an interesting perspective on where the company was and the changes he wanted to make when he joined Docusign from Google.
Of course, that brought us to AI. Allan and I spent a long time talking about the idea that Docusign should summarize contracts for people before they sign them and who is responsible if the AI gets that interpretation wrong. We also spent a while talking about how Docusign‚Äôs customers actually generate the kinds of documents that get signed and how automating that process with AI does and does not work. You‚Äôll hear Allan point out that a lot of this looks like just a fancy mail merge, which was at least refreshingly down to earth in the context of an AI conversation.
I also had to ask Allan which parts of his enterprise software were bad and how he‚Äôd improve them ‚Äî he actually answered the question, which might be a first for an enterprise software CEO. This is a good one; there‚Äôs even a couple dunks on Google in the mix, as you‚Äôll hear.
Okay: Allan Thygesen, CEO of Docusign. Here we go.
This interview has been lightly edited for length and clarity.
Allan Thygesen, you are the CEO of Docusign. Welcome to Decoder.
Thank you, Nilay. Good to be here.
I‚Äôm excited to talk to you. I always love it when an enterprise software CEO comes on the show. Most of your competitors in enterprise software are very reticent to show up and answer the first question: When was the last time you used your end product?
This morning.
What did you sign? Can you say?
I signed an agreement for our procurement team, but yesterday I signed your appearance release form.
Very good. I think it‚Äôs the most important question for enterprise software CEOs because on the whole, the experience of using enterprise software is, I would say, pretty dicey.
It‚Äôs not great. I agree.
And Docusign is a weird one. It‚Äôs in the background of everything all the time. Most people don‚Äôt use it. I think a lot of lawyers and maybe procurement teams use the product. Most people sort of experience Docusign. How do you think about that?
I mean, it is sort of a two-sided network, right? So, we sell to businesses and other organizations that want to prepare and send documents for signature. That‚Äôs historically been our business. Then, consumers or other companies sign documents. They‚Äôre the counterparty. But they don‚Äôt pay us anything. So, most people have experienced us that way. If you work at a company or organization that uses Docusign, you may have experienced being on the sending side of approvals or other functionality.
That business is really interesting to me. Docusign as a company is interesting, most notably because it‚Äôs been an independent company for 20-some years. It‚Äôs a public company. From what I experience ‚Äî again, as somebody who just experiences Docusign ‚Äî it‚Äôs just there. It‚Äôs just in the background of almost everything I do.
But it‚Äôs shocking to me that it hasn‚Äôt been acquired or people haven‚Äôt tried to acquire Docusign. The product range hasn‚Äôt dramatically expanded in other ways.
It‚Äôs expanding now.
We‚Äôll come to that. And it‚Äôs in the way that everyone‚Äôs expanding, right? Now the chatbots are going to do all the work for us. But how do you think about the fact that it has been effectively one product experience all this time? What has made it resilient in that way?
You‚Äôre right. We are a little over 20 years old. The original idea was to help companies and individuals sign agreements online. At the beginning, no one thought that was a good idea. Not regulators, not companies, not consumers. So, there was a tremendous amount of trust building across those three constituencies that happened over time. But as you said, we became trusted for a variety of transactions over time. Now, it‚Äôs in the water across companies of all sizes and functions.
Look, we did come up with a great idea, and when you have a good idea, you want to run with it. I think Docusign has done a really good job of that. With that said, part of my goal joining about three years ago was to say, ‚ÄúOkay, that‚Äôs an amazing foundation. We‚Äôre privileged that people have positive associations, and we‚Äôre used by 1.8 million companies. What do we do for an encore? How do we broaden the platform?‚Äù
We‚Äôve had some ideas on that for a while, thinking about the entire agreement journey, but we‚Äôd never really put it all together. We‚Äôd never gone beyond the marketing side of identifying that problem to actually delivering solutions that could solve it. I think that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre doing now. So, that‚Äôs very exciting. But the signature piece is a foundation. That is the most pivotal moment in the life cycle of an agreement. It‚Äôs a very high value, high stress moment for many people. Making that simple and delightful was a very meaningful value proposition. And it‚Äôs a lot harder than it looks.
Again, I‚Äôve ‚Äúsigned‚Äù Docusigns. My signature in Docusign has no relationship to my actual signature. Docusign just generates some cursive that says my name. What is a signature? In Docusign‚Äôs worldview, what is a signature?
A signature to me is where identity and consent commingle. With the identity aspect, there are a lot of things we do to identify you. Obviously, this thing comes to you in your email, via SMS, or WhatsApp. We do all kinds of IP tracing and other things to validate that you are the intended recipient if you‚Äôre the signer. That whole trail is then auditable and can be used in a court of law. It‚Äôs a perfect substitute for a wet signature that you might otherwise have used in practically all cases. There are a few states in the US that still require you to sign something in person, but we‚Äôve done a pretty good job over time getting to a place where that‚Äôs felt super secure.
From the consent perspective, you‚Äôre right. It could be a dot, it could be a checkbox, could be a signature. It‚Äôs almost less important. There are some personal expression aspects, but it‚Äôs the identity piece that‚Äôs the most important, along with the fact that you take a step that indicates consent.
Just to make that as reductive and simple as possible, it sounds like the service that you‚Äôre providing as Docusign is, ‚ÄúYou know who I am. You know who the other part of the agreement is.‚Äù I hit the button and your database says, ‚ÄúThis person that we verified hit that button and they say they agree.‚Äù Then, if the contract comes into question, you can say, ‚ÄúWell, you definitely signed it. Maybe you disagree on the terms, but you definitely signed the contract. Let‚Äôs argue about that.‚Äù That implies fundamentally that a product is just a big database of identities and then a marking of consent. In the most reductive way possible, is that how you think about it?
That‚Äôs the aspect on the execution side. There‚Äôs all the stuff that leads up to preparing a document for execution. We have a lot of products that you as a signer would not see, but that companies use to get documents ready for signing, and to get them approved internally to maybe customize them for you. Let‚Äôs say I‚Äôm running a big sales team ‚Äî let‚Äôs say the Docusign sales team ‚Äî and I want to send that agreement to Decoder so you can use Docusign for your releases. I can automatically mass customize a standard template using Docusign‚Äôs functionality that‚Äôs embedded in Salesforce and other CRMs.
That‚Äôs an example of the type of workflows that we do. We do that for hiring, for procurement, for new vendor onboarding, all those tools that lead up to that magical signature moment where it is, I think, about identity and consent.
Even that part where you say, ‚ÄúOkay, we‚Äôre going to generate a bunch of documents,‚Äù is downstream of the first product, which is signing. The reason I ask about it in that reductive way is because there are a lot of ways you could verify identity and mark consent. You have a lot of competitors there.
We do that.
Is Docusign‚Äôs dominance and market leadership based on just network effect? It exists, it‚Äôs the one you can use, it‚Äôs won over your trust, and because so many people have already used it, it‚Äôs the easiest thing to use?
I do think that the network effect is very important. People choose Docusign in part because they know that the recipients ‚Äî consumers mostly ‚Äî trust it. Maybe if you‚Äôre a giant bank and you have an existing relationship with a customer and you‚Äôre sending something to them, that matters a little less. But for most companies in the world and most situations, like all new customer onboarding, that trust component is super important.
Now, to the other thing that was implied in your question: what about identity and these alternative technologies for establishing identity? We could sort of see that coming, We worked on a federated identity strategy to give you all kinds of identity validation at different levels of risk. We let people do knowledge-based authentication. That‚Äôs sort of on its way out, but that‚Äôs answering those questions that you would probably remember. Where did you live on the street 10 years ago?
We do biometric-based identification like video or we can link up with the Apple and Google stuff. We do risk-based assessments so we can fork you to validation mechanisms. We use the new digital IDs. So in the US, that‚Äôs Clear or ID.me, which is the government one that the IRS uses. In Europe, many governments have a national digital ID, along with many other parts of the world. We go all the way up to a notary solution with online notaries. So whatever your risk assessment, whatever you feel is the appropriate trade-off between convenience and security, we can give you all those solutions turnkey in one platform. Then, at the end, most of the time, you‚Äôre also legally required to give a signature.
When you think about that journey, who are your biggest customers? Is it just big banks? Is it mom-and-pops? How does that break down for you?
We‚Äôre incredibly diversified. We‚Äôre used by, as I mentioned, 1.8 million companies. If you have that many customers, most of them are going to be small. But we are used by over 95 percent of the Fortune 500 and equivalent in other international markets, many mid-sized companies, and then a huge long tail of small companies. And no one company represents any meaningful share of our business. That said, our biggest customers tend to be banks or other large companies that have high volumes of high value agreements. If you have agreements that matter and you‚Äôre entering them in large volumes, you‚Äôre very likely to be a Docusign customer.
Is that the push for growth? I do want to talk about your expansion into other kinds of products and services. Is part of that that you‚Äôre just out of big customers? There‚Äôs no more fish in the sea?
We already have most large companies in the world as customers, but of course there‚Äôs so much more we can do for them beyond the signing piece. And we‚Äôre certainly not done with the signing piece. I mean, you go and audit the large banks who‚Äôve been with us for over a decade on how many of their agreements are actually automated, digitized, and executed electronically, and it‚Äôs 20 or 30 percent because people take the biggest high-value workflows and everything else is left to the side. So, we have a lot of opportunity. If we can make that more efficient and easy to do, we can close that gap, as well as provide broader value in all other aspects of the agreement cycle.
Talk to me about that. There‚Äôs identity and signing, which I was very curious about. I don‚Äôt think most people ever spend time with the notion that a signature represents many complex concepts underneath. That‚Äôs the first part.
Then there‚Äôs the part where, okay, we‚Äôre generating documents for signature. We might as well help draft the documents, prepare them and get them approved for that final step. I want to understand that a little bit. Then, there‚Äôs obviously your expansion into AI and other tools and parts of the workflow. At what point do you run into Microsoft Word? Where is the boundary of some of that work, and where are the boundaries of some of those opportunities?
We ran into Microsoft Word the day we got started, right? Microsoft Word is where 90 percent of legal documents get authored. That‚Äôs the tool most lawyers use. That‚Äôs where documents are crafted and often negotiated, redlined, etc. So, we‚Äôve always been deeply integrated with Word and, of course, with Google as well. Frankly, with all of the tools that people use to do their jobs. I mean, we‚Äôve had a 20-year partnership with Salesforce. We were the first or second vendor on the app exchange and deeply embedded in their flows. We do similar work with Workday, SAP, and so on.
I don‚Äôt think that we or Microsoft have ever thought about competing with each other. I worked at Google for 12 years before taking this job,so a similar scale company, and you take on the biggest, broadest opportunities in your office suites. Yeah, you might add more and more features to your office suite, but you don‚Äôt want to add a separate workflow or things that are too specific. You rely on your ecosystem for that. And that‚Äôs what Google and Microsoft have done.
They‚Äôll both allow you to render a signature inside of a doc that you author in those packages, but no one thinks that‚Äôs a substitute for Docusign for all the reasons we‚Äôve discussed. It literally doesn‚Äôt come up with customers. I‚Äôve never heard anybody say, ‚ÄúWell, maybe I could use Microsoft Word or Google.‚Äù That has never happened in my three-plus years here.
I‚Äôm just thinking about our listeners who, again, I think most people experience Docusign and then I know a bunch of lawyers who ‚Äî
You get a PDF and that‚Äôs how they experience it.
That‚Äôs how they experience it. It‚Äôs all of the steps leading up to experiencing Docusign that are fascinating to me.
So when you say, ‚ÄúHelp prepare a document for signature,‚Äù there‚Äôs the drafting, right? There‚Äôs Microsoft Word‚Ä¶ honestly, Microsoft Word might be the reason I‚Äôm not a lawyer anymore. I was like, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt use this software anymore.‚Äù There‚Äôs the Microsoft Word of it where we‚Äôre going to redline a bunch of stuff. We have the document. From that point, what do you mean by ‚Äúprepare a document for signature‚Äù? What are the services Docusign provides?
Some contracts are completely custom crafted, right? I think you‚Äôre a lawyer, right? So, most contracts start with a template of some kind. Maybe it‚Äôs a template for something really complex, like an M&A agreement, or something really simple, like an NDA, or anything in between. It could be a master service agreement between a company and another company or a license agreement, but they always have a template.
Then, they tailor it, with a sort of legal tailoring, right? I want to have different limitations of liability, I want different payment terms. And some of it is, let‚Äôs say, mass customization. I want to get the data about that customer and some things we‚Äôve already negotiated, and I want that to flow automatically from whatever the system of record is. Could be Salesforce, could be Workday, could be SAP, could be whatever. And I want to populate that into the agreement. So this template that I have gets personalized and customized. That‚Äôs also what happens in consumer applications. The forms that you get from Chase or Wells Fargo are mass customized that way. That‚Äôs essentially a data pool.
So, that‚Äôs what I mean when I say ‚Äúcustomized‚Äù or ‚Äúpersonalized.‚Äù Now, there are a lot of things that can flow from that. Let‚Äôs say you are a national employer, but you need to take into account employment laws in the 50 states. That would be an example of a customization that‚Äôs a bit more complicated. That gets even worse if you‚Äôre a global employer and you have to craft offer letters in 180 countries. That starts getting pretty complex. But there are rules. We have a system for applying those kinds of rules so that you can have global standards but still create documents that are tailored to local laws and customs.
This gets me right into the opportunity for AI broadly, which is that you‚Äôre starting to do some of the lawyering a bit, right? You‚Äôre saying we‚Äôre not going to hire the junior associate to figure out the local law. We can actually just programmatically make a contract that‚Äì
For that type of application, correct. We‚Äôll come back to this, but I think there are two big use cases for us. One is to make agreement workflows more efficient, sometimes just by automating them and sometimes by re-imagining them. That‚Äôs a huge part of what we do. This mass customization is not a new thing. That‚Äôs been going on for a while. It‚Äôs sort of advanced mail merge, right?
[Laughs] You said it. I didn‚Äôt want to say it. You said it.
It is! But look, it‚Äôs really good. It saves a lot of time and a lot of companies live with that.
If I could start a business that was charging a premium on mail merge, I would do it too.
Oh my god, yeah. Managing people‚Äôs address books is another one that would be very valuable. No one has solved that.
But anyway, making workflows more efficient and now tackling all of the steps in the agreement process is a part of what we‚Äôre doing. So, we‚Äôre tackling things like the ingestion of agreements. We have a whole queuing system where a sales or procurement rep can trigger the sending of documents with legal. It can get an automatic first review, then it gets assigned to a lawyer. The lawyer does a quick end edit, and everyone has real-time status. That‚Äôs an example of re-imagining legal workflow, which today is totally asynchronous email, unpredictable, and non-transparent. That‚Äôs one piece. I think that‚Äôs what people have historically focused on with contract management.
Then, the other piece is to take AI and extract data out of the agreements to run my business better. That‚Äôs something that was conceptually possible historically, but it was just too heavy and hard to do with legacy LLMs. Now, we can do that completely automated. So, I can go to people and say, ‚ÄúHey, you have 5,000 agreements with me. Would you like to know what‚Äôs in them? Let me highlight how these agreements deviate from agreements with peers. Company X is coming up for renewal in 90 days. How can I review that? How can I know what I should be renegotiating?‚Äù
I can give you that using AI, which is automated right off the shelf. It leverages the fact that you already used Docusign and you‚Äôve already stored your agreements with us. It uses modern AI, and then adds, of course, some workflow and automation on top.
Let me take a beat here and just ask the Decoder question so I have a better sense of the company itself. How is Docusign structured? How many people is it and how are they organized?
Docusign has a little under 7,000 employees, and our structure has gone through some transformation. Historically, I would say Docusign, ignoring the very early days of conceiving the product, evolved into a very sales centered company. Most customers interface with Docusign through sales. We had a very large sales team. That was the most powerful function of the company. Things flowed from there and were optimized around that.
When I joined, I very quickly realized we needed to completely reimagine our product roadmap. I really wanted to put product at the center of the company and say, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to articulate a new product roadmap, and things are going to flow from there.‚Äù That‚Äôs not to say that we‚Äôre not taking lots of customer input. After all, we‚Äôve got 20 years of experience working in agreements with millions of customers, but we want the product vision and the overall architecture to be the guiding light for how we go to market, how we spend, etc.
The second area I focused on was marketing. Historically, marketing here worked in the service of sales. It was basically about creating qualified leads for sales. But I was like, ‚ÄúThis is an electronic contracting product. They should be able to just come in and do whatever they want to do directly, self-serve to the greatest extent possible.‚Äù I came from Google where every advertiser, including people who spent more than $1 billion per year, places their own orders in the system. But we somehow couldn‚Äôt do that at Docusign. So, that was another area. It was about taking all the pieces of the company that worked on identifying, sourcing, and bringing new customers on, and combining them in one team.
Then, there‚Äôs the third area that I‚Äôm really pushing on. We‚Äôve always felt like we needed to own the ball. When you have an iconic, simple product, you maybe don‚Äôt need partners as much, but now with this broader vision for agreement management, we really need partners to help us go to market and install and service the product. So, we‚Äôre very focused on working with system integrators like the Deloittes and Accentures of the world, as well as distributors and resellers. Those are the big changes we‚Äôve made.
I have to say, 7,000 people is a shocking number. The last number I heard was 4,000, which was shocking then. How are 7,000 people organized at Docusign? Is it sales and marketing? Is it product?

Can you bring those together? That‚Äôs why I asked if the foundation seems stable because eventually, one of those things is going to be more lucrative than the other. You might run out of enterprise model providers, and that industry might collapse to one or two that charge high rates.
I think both are so large that the biggest players are going to go after both but on very different teams. Obviously, we‚Äôre very familiar with Google. Google Cloud is a standalone operating unit inside of Google and operates separately, and necessarily so, right? In fact, I don‚Äôt think Google Cloud could have become successful if it wasn‚Äôt pulled away from Google‚Äôs traditional consumer services and ad business. OpenAI is a smaller company, but is going to need to replicate that very different MO and go-to-market that comes with the ads business in the consumer side of the house versus the enterprise side.
That‚Äôs a lot to take on for a young company. It‚Äôs an incredibly capable team with a huge amount of IP, but that is a very ambitious undertaking to do both. Anthropic seems to have decided to focus exclusively on the enterprise and executing that incredibly well. We‚Äôre using Claude Code and it‚Äôs fantastic, so huge kudos to it. Then, there‚Äôll be a host of other players that become either more enterprise or more consumer focused. But I think Google, Meta, and OpenAI are probably the three that are trying to do both. Meta is probably more consumer-y right now, but clearly has ambitions in the enterprise.
Are you structuring your contracts with these vendors to be long-term or short-term? How do you think about that?
The contracts in that space tend to be relatively long-term. We and they want three-plus-year, commitment-type deals. As much as people want to say, ‚ÄúOh, I can just swap one for the other,‚Äù that‚Äôs not really how things work if you‚Äôre doing enterprise deployment. So, there‚Äôs significant investment in pointing to a platform. And the vendor, of course, wants to see the benefit of your growth and the upfront investment they‚Äôre making in helping you come onto their platform. And so they‚Äôre three-plus-year deals, sometimes longer.
When do you think you‚Äôll have a feature set using these tools that‚Äôs so robust that you can actually charge a premium to all of your customers? Or do you think it will always be ‚Äî
We kind of do that today. We went from being a signed provider. We‚Äôre charging a substantial premium from moving to this AI-assisted suite because of the value. I can provide that value instantly, right? You signed with Docusign, and I can turn on and give you AI insights into your agreements on day one. In fact, we deploy our new products as fast as we can deploy. We deploy in under 20 days, which is kind of unheard of. If you follow enterprise software, that‚Äôs kind of unheard of. And frankly, a lot of that is just human stuff because the product is ready on day one.
I think we sign agreements with customers‚Ä¶ Our customer agreements right now are around 19 months on average, but they‚Äôre longer with big customers and tend to be shorter with smaller customers. That‚Äôs a typical pattern. I expect that our agreements will get longer over time, but we already charge a substantial premium to get access to the AI features and customers have been very willing to pay. We have over 25,000 customers live on this new AI platform under 18 months.
I‚Äôm always curious about that number, and then I want to wrap up. I‚Äôm always curious about that number. I hear these usage numbers from all the companies that deploy AI tools, and underneath it is, well, it just showed up one day and we‚Äôre counting that person as an AI user, right? AI overviews are there, everyone loves them and it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know about that. They just are in my face whether I want them there.‚Äù
Are you actually measuring happy customers using the tools because they want to or because the button is there and everyone just clicks it?
Both. Look, we give you a license for however many users you want. We obviously track the consumption of that license, what are people doing, how often they access their repository, how many searches they do, how many extractions they do, and how many document sendings and document executions they do? We keep a very close eye on that as fundamental health metrics.
I think product adoption leads to renewal and retention, and we are very focused on that. No, not everyone uses the AI features, but we‚Äôre seeing really robust usage. We‚Äôre constantly looking for more ways for users to discover what‚Äôs possible. This is one of the endemic problems of enterprise software. You build this stuff, but how do people actually figure out what‚Äôs possible?
The good news is we have something that has a near universal value prop and can be deployed easily. There are all kinds of magic moments where, ‚ÄúOh, did you know you could do this? ‚Äù We‚Äôre making that available. So, as you send a document or sign a document, ‚ÄúHey, would you like an agreement somewhere? Would you like to know how this agreement pairs? Hey, did you know that we have all of them and you can see all this stuff?‚Äù It‚Äôs a new world. It‚Äôs exciting.
I do love that the future of all software is some combination of ultra smart Clippy and Tooltips. There‚Äôs something there, someone should write a book on it.
[Laughs] Hopefully we‚Äôre providing more value than that.
You‚Äôre an enterprise software CEO. You‚Äôve come and you‚Äôve faced the gauntlet. So, I‚Äôm going to ask you the hardest question of all. You use your own tools. You started off by saying you use your own tools. What is your biggest frustration with Docusign and how would you fix it as a product?
I don‚Äôt think our mobile experience is good enough. I would expect that everything should automatically flow. We should predict the next steps. It all works. Obviously millions of people sign with Docusign daily and often on their phones, but I think there‚Äôs still some room for improvement there. So, I‚Äôm pushing the team on that.
Well done. You actually answered the question. Most enterprise software CEOs don‚Äôt, so I commend you for that. Allan, this has been great. Thank you so much for being on Decoder.
Thank you, Nilay. I really appreciate you having me.
Questions or comments about this episode? Hit us up at decoder@theverge.com. We really do read every email!

articles.title: Dragon Quest gets another great remake that‚Äôs perfect for newcomers
articles.author: Andrew Webster
articles.excerpt: When a video game series goes on for a long time, it raises a question for newcomers: Just where is the best place to jump in? In the case of Dragon Quest, there are nearly a dozen mainline titles,...
articles.content:
When a video game series goes on for a long time, it raises a question for newcomers: Just where is the best place to jump in? In the case of Dragon Quest, there are nearly a dozen mainline titles, not to mention copious spinoffs and ports that span four decades of history. Of late, though, publisher Square Enix has been releasing a number of remakes that serve as almost ideal entry points for beginners who are intimidated by all of that baggage. And the new Dragon Quest VII Reimagined might just be the best so far.
Dragon Quest gets another great remake that‚Äôs perfect for newcomers
Dragon Quest VII Reimagined might be the most approachable game in the series to date.
Dragon Quest VII Reimagined might be the most approachable game in the series to date.
DQVII was a pivotal game for the series when it launched on the original PlayStation, as it was the first with 3D graphics. For a franchise that evolves at a slow, deliberate pace, that was a big deal. Maybe that‚Äôs why this isn‚Äôt the first time Square Enix has remade it; the game also launched on the Nintendo 3DS under the new subtitle Fragments of the Forgotten Past. Reimagined builds on the core experience with a number of quality-of-life tweaks ‚Äî you can see enemies before battle starts, for instance, and the game gives you a ‚Äúpreviously on‚Äù story update each time you start it up ‚Äî along with revamped graphics that make the game world look like a series of cute-as-heck dioramas. It doesn‚Äôt quite approach the handcrafted charm of Fantasian, but it‚Äôs close.
That stuff is great and makes Reimagined feel like a thoroughly modern game. But what really makes it a great entry point for Dragon Quest beginners is the way it‚Äôs structured. For the most part, every Dragon Quest is a standalone experience that tells its own story, so narrative-wise there‚Äôs no real issue with jumping into the series with any specific number, including the seventh game. But what makes DQVII unique is how its premise turns it into a series of episodes that are much more digestible than one single, epic quest.
Unlike most Dragon Quest games, and most other fantasy RPGs for that matter, DQVII isn‚Äôt set in one huge world. Instead, the game opens on a tiny island, one where the residents believe it‚Äôs literally the only place in the world. Of course, that turns out to not exactly be the case, as other islands slowly start to appear and you, the plucky hero, are also able to piece together magical tablets that whisk you to faraway realms.
DQVII still has the epic scope of a traditional RPG, but this structure ‚Äî which has you exploring these new islands and locations one at a time ‚Äî makes it easier to both play in bite-sized chunks and remember just what the heck is going on. There‚Äôs an overarching story, but because each area has its own distinct storyline, the game ends up feeling almost like a series of chapters you tackle individually. I never really found myself lost in the story ‚Äî thanks in part to the recap feature ‚Äî nor did I find myself lost in the world itself, unsure of where to go next. And the islands are all pretty delightful places to explore; one moment you‚Äôre investigating a strange ritual in a giant volcano, the next you‚Äôre visiting a farming village where everyone has been turned into an animal.
It‚Äôs the combination of visual refresh, streamlined quality-of-life features, and less-intimidating structure that makes Reimagined such a good entry point. It‚Äôs also not alone. Dragon Quest has been incredibly popular in Japan since its inception, but has gradually grown its audience in the rest of the world. And over the last few years in particular, Square Enix has released a handful of titles that I consider to be great starter games. If you‚Äôre looking for something with a little bit more of a retro feel, the remake of Dragon Quest III ‚Äî part of the publisher‚Äôs fascinating HD-2D line of games ‚Äî manages to strike the right blend of depth and approachability. It‚Äôs straightforward in a way that turns into something like RPG comfort food. And for something larger in scope, there‚Äôs always Dragon Quest XI, the most recent mainline entry in the series, which takes the familiar DQ gameplay and bolts on high-end graphics and cutscenes that make it feel more like a modern epic.
But I think that Reimagined has those games beat when it comes to being welcoming. Every DQ game is charming, and every modern release has quality-of-life tweaks that make it more palatable compared to older RPGs. But the narrative structure of DQVII turns a huge adventure into a series of smaller, digestible stories, making it easier to play on your own terms. So if you‚Äôve been wondering what the deal with blue slimes is, this is your best chance to find out.
Dragon Quest VII Reimagined launches on February 5th on the Switch, PS5, Xbox, and PC.
